guides.pageDescription: Step-by-step instructions for manually submitting your tax returns to HMRC. Follow these guides to ensure accurate and timely filing.
guides.disclaimer: These guides are for informational purposes only and do not constitute tax advice. Always verify information with HMRC or a qualified tax professional. HMRC portal interfaces may change; screenshots are for illustration only.

vat.title: VAT Return Filing Guide
vat.intro: This guide walks you through the process of submitting your VAT return to HMRC through their online portal. Your VAT data from the app can be used to fill in the required fields.
vat.prereq1: Your Government Gateway user ID and password
vat.prereq3: Your sales and purchase records for the VAT period
vat.prereq4: Your calculated VAT figures from this app

step1.title: Sign in to HMRC Online Services
step1.description: Access the HMRC online services portal using your Government Gateway credentials.
step1.sub2: Click 'Sign in' and enter your Government Gateway user ID
step1.sub3: Enter your password and complete any two-factor authentication if prompted
step1.tip: If you've forgotten your Government Gateway credentials, you can recover them on the login page.

step2.title: Navigate to Your VAT Account
step2.description: Once logged in, access your VAT account from the dashboard.
step2.screenshotAlt: HMRC business tax account showing VAT section
step2.sub1: From your Business Tax Account dashboard, click on 'VAT'
step2.sub2: You'll see your VAT account summary including any returns due

step3.title: Start Your VAT Return
step3.description: Begin the VAT return submission process for the current period.
step3.sub1: Click 'Submit VAT Return' or 'Complete VAT Return'
step3.sub2: Confirm the VAT period you are submitting for
step3.sub3: Review any obligations or deadlines shown
step3.tip: Make sure you're submitting for the correct VAT period. The dates should match your accounting records.

step4.title: Enter Your VAT Figures
step4.description: Fill in the 9-box VAT return form with your calculated figures. Use the values from your app as shown in the field mappings below.
step4.screenshotAlt: HMRC VAT return form showing boxes 1-9
step4.warning: Double-check all figures before proceeding. Incorrect entries may result in penalties or interest charges.

step5.title: Review Your VAT Return
step5.description: Carefully review all entered figures before submission.
step5.sub1: Check that Box 3 equals Box 1 plus Box 2
step5.sub2: Verify Box 5 equals Box 3 minus Box 4
step5.sub3: Ensure all figures match your accounting records
step5.warning: You cannot amend a VAT return after submission. Any corrections must be made in your next VAT return or by contacting HMRC.

step6.title: Submit Your VAT Return
step6.description: Confirm the declaration and submit your VAT return to HMRC.
step6.screenshotAlt: HMRC VAT return submission confirmation page
step6.sub1: Read and accept the declaration statement
step6.sub2: Click 'Submit' to send your return to HMRC
step6.tip: Save or print your submission receipt for your records.

step7.title: Make Payment or Claim Refund
step7.description: If VAT is due (Box 5 is positive), arrange payment. If you're due a refund (Box 5 is negative), it will be processed automatically.
step7.sub1: If paying: Note the payment reference and amount due
step7.sub2: Set up a Direct Debit, pay by bank transfer, or use another payment method
step7.sub3: Keep records of your payment confirmation
step7.tip: Setting up a Direct Debit ensures you never miss a payment deadline.

fields.box1Desc: VAT charged on all goods and services sold during this period
fields.box2Desc: VAT due on goods acquired from EU countries (if applicable)
fields.box3Desc: Sum of Box 1 and Box 2 (calculated automatically)
fields.box4Desc: VAT reclaimed on purchases and expenses for business use
fields.box5Desc: Difference between Box 3 and Box 4 (amount to pay or reclaim)
fields.box6Desc: Total value of all sales and outputs excluding VAT
fields.box7Desc: Total value of all purchases and inputs excluding VAT
fields.box8Desc: Total value of goods supplied to EU countries
fields.box9Desc: Total value of goods acquired from EU countries

vat.deadlineInfo: Your VAT return and payment are due 1 calendar month and 7 days after the end of your VAT accounting period. Late submissions may incur penalties.

ct.title: Corporation Tax (CT600) Filing Guide
ct.intro: This guide helps you file your Company Tax Return (CT600) with HMRC. Corporation Tax returns are more complex than VAT and typically require professional preparation.
ct.prereq1: Your Government Gateway user ID and password
ct.prereq5: Full accounting records for the period

step1.title: Sign in to HMRC Online Services
step1.description: Access the HMRC online services portal using your Government Gateway credentials for your company.
step1.sub2: Sign in with your company's Government Gateway credentials
step1.tip: Make sure you're using the Government Gateway account linked to your company, not your personal account.

step2.title: Access Corporation Tax Services
step2.description: Navigate to the Corporation Tax section from your business tax dashboard.
step2.screenshotAlt: HMRC business tax account showing Corporation Tax section
step2.sub1: From the Business Tax Account, select 'Corporation Tax'
step2.sub2: View your company's Corporation Tax overview
step2.sub3: Check for any outstanding returns or payments due

step3.title: Prepare Your CT600 Return
step3.description: Before starting online, ensure you have all required information ready.
step3.sub1: Prepare your company's full accounts for the period
step3.sub2: Calculate your taxable profits using your accounting records
step3.sub3: Identify any reliefs or deductions you're entitled to claim
step3.warning: CT600 returns are complex. Consider using professional accounting software or consulting an accountant.

step4.title: Start Your CT600 Return
step4.description: Begin filling in the CT600 form for your accounting period.
step4.sub2: Confirm your company details and accounting period
step4.sub3: Select which supplementary pages apply to your company

step5.title: Enter Financial Information
step5.description: Input your company's financial figures from your accounts. Use the field mappings below to match app values to HMRC fields.
step5.tip: Keep your annual accounts open alongside for reference as you complete each section.

step6.title: Attach Accounts and Computations
step6.description: Upload or attach your company accounts and tax computations.
step6.sub1: Attach your full annual accounts in iXBRL format
step6.sub3: Add any supplementary schedules if required
step6.warning: HMRC requires accounts in iXBRL format for online filing. Check your accounting software can produce these.

step7.title: Review and Submit
step7.description: Carefully review your CT600 return before final submission.
step7.screenshotAlt: HMRC CT600 review and submit page
step7.sub1: Check all figures match your prepared accounts
step7.sub2: Verify the Corporation Tax liability calculation
step7.sub3: Accept the declaration and submit your return
step7.tip: Download and save a copy of your submitted return for your records.

step8.title: Pay Corporation Tax
step8.description: Arrange payment of any Corporation Tax due within the deadline.
step8.sub1: Note the payment reference number provided
step8.sub2: Choose your payment method (bank transfer, Direct Debit, etc.)
step8.sub3: Pay by the deadline (9 months and 1 day after accounting period ends)
step8.sub4: Keep confirmation of payment for your records
step8.tip: Large companies may need to pay in quarterly instalments. Check if this applies to you.

fields.turnoverDesc: Total sales and other income for the accounting period
fields.tradingProfitsDesc: Profit from your company's trade before deductions
fields.netTradingProfitsDesc: Trading profits after capital allowances and other adjustments
fields.chargableProfitsDesc: Total profits subject to Corporation Tax
fields.ctPayableDesc: Amount of Corporation Tax due for this period
fields.taxRefundDesc: Amount due back if you've overpaid or have losses to carry back

ct.deadlineInfo: There are different deadlines for filing your return and paying tax:
ct.deadlineReturn: CT600 Return: 12 months after the end of your accounting period
ct.deadlinePayment: Tax Payment: 9 months and 1 day after the end of your accounting period

sa.title: Self Assessment Filing Guide
sa.intro: This guide walks you through completing your Self Assessment tax return online. Self Assessment is used to report income from self-employment, rental income, dividends, and other sources.
sa.prereq1: Your Government Gateway user ID and password
sa.prereq4: Records of all income for the tax year (6 April to 5 April)
sa.prereq5: Details of any tax already paid (P60, P45, etc.)

step1.title: Sign in to HMRC Online Services
step1.description: Access the HMRC Self Assessment portal using your personal Government Gateway account.
step1.sub2: Sign in with your personal Government Gateway user ID
step1.sub3: Complete identity verification if this is your first time
step1.tip: If you haven't registered for Self Assessment, you must do so before you can file. Allow time for HMRC to send your activation code.

step2.title: Access Your Self Assessment Account
step2.description: Navigate to your Self Assessment section from your personal tax account.
step2.screenshotAlt: HMRC personal tax account showing Self Assessment section
step2.sub1: From your Personal Tax Account, select 'Self Assessment'
step2.sub2: Review any messages or notices from HMRC

step3.title: Start Your Tax Return
step3.description: Begin a new Self Assessment return for the relevant tax year.
step3.sub2: Confirm the tax year (6 April to 5 April)
step3.sub3: Answer the tailoring questions to determine which sections you need
step3.sub4: The system will show you which pages to complete based on your answers
step3.tip: Answer the tailoring questions carefully. This ensures you complete all required sections and skip irrelevant ones.

step4.title: Complete Personal Details
step4.description: Verify and update your personal information.
step4.screenshotAlt: HMRC Self Assessment personal details page
step4.sub1: Check your name, address, and date of birth are correct
step4.sub2: Update your contact details if needed

step5.title: Enter Income Details
step5.description: Report all sources of income for the tax year. Use the field mappings below to enter values from the app.
step5.warning: Report ALL income, even if tax was already deducted at source. HMRC cross-references multiple data sources.

step6.title: Complete Self-Employment Section
step6.description: If you're self-employed, complete the self-employment pages with your business income and expenses.
step6.tip: Keep detailed records of all business expenses. You can claim allowable expenses to reduce your tax bill.

step7.title: Enter Reliefs and Deductions
step7.description: Claim any tax reliefs you're entitled to.
step7.sub1: Pension contributions (if not deducted at source)

step8.title: Review and Submit
step8.description: Check your tax calculation and submit your return.
step8.screenshotAlt: HMRC Self Assessment tax calculation summary
step8.sub2: Check all income sources are included
step8.warning: Once submitted, you have 12 months to make corrections. After that, you'll need to write to HMRC.

step9.title: Pay Any Tax Due
step9.description: If tax is owed, arrange payment before the deadline.
step9.sub1: Note the amount due and payment reference
step9.sub3: Pay by 31 January (or set up a Time to Pay arrangement if needed)
step9.sub4: Consider payments on account for next year
step9.tip: You can set up a budget payment plan to spread your tax payments throughout the year.

fields.turnoverDesc: Total income from self-employment before expenses
fields.expensesDesc: Business expenses that can be deducted
fields.employmentIncomeDesc: Salary and wages from employment (before tax)
fields.dividendsDesc: Dividends received from UK and foreign companies
fields.savingsInterestDesc: Interest from bank accounts and investments

sa.deadlinePaper: Paper returns: 31 October after the tax year ends
sa.deadlineOnline: Online returns: 31 January after the tax year ends
sa.deadlinePayment: Tax payment: 31 January after the tax year ends
sa.paymentOnAccountInfo: If your tax bill is Â£1,000 or more, you may need to make advance payments towards next year's bill. These are called 'payments on account' and are due on 31 January and 31 July.
